moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Bf4 g6 3. h3: My typical questionable move, that provides a square for the bishop to retire, supports an early g4, which denies f5 to the black's dsb... if e3, Nh4 and my dsb will be exchanged. It is not a catastrophe, but I don't like it.
moves.3... Bg7 4. c3: The typical c4 allows black counterplay on the diagonal. I want to solid block the queenside and attack on the kingside. I'm a little "naive" here, since black can calmly develop and wait. A queenside castling could be advisable later.
moves.4... d5 5. g4: No bf4. Plus, a pawn's storm project on the kingside.
moves.5... Nc6: Losing flexibility. c5 is a move black should have in mind all the time, specially if he wants to castle kingside disregarding the white clouds approaching.
moves.6. e3: In order to advance g5, I have to make impossible for the knight to go to h4.
moves.6... O-O: Black seems to be ok, but in fact he is not. Black's lsb has just d7, and the queen cannot move.
moves.7. Be2: Now, no Nh4. It can go to e, but I have to accept it.
moves.7... Re8: Preparing a break on e5, of course.
moves.8. g5: This allows Bf5, but I want to attack.
moves.8... Ne4: Despite its prominency, this knight is not all that strong here, unless black manages to sac it. But he has no play on the dark squares...
moves.9... Bd7: Good, black has not a plan. As you can see, this move doesn't solve anything to black.
moves.10. h4: Thinking on h5, of course. But it has the offside that allows...
moves.10... Bg4: Nb-d2 was ok, but I wanted to manage the situation in another way.
moves.11. Nh2 Bxe2 12. Qxe2 e5: ...but in the meanwhile, I forgot about the e5 push blacks were preparing. And now, this is really dangerous, since I have a rook in front my queen and king.
moves.13. Bg3 Nxg3 14. fxg3 exd4 15. cxd4 Nxd4: Stay calm. Nh2 covers the nasty fork.
moves.16... Nc6: No need to take back the knight, since I still have to move my king. But where? I saw that after Nc3, d5 was very dangerous. So I opted for quickness...
moves.18. Qf2: Counterattacking on f7. This is hardly a threat, since I need more strenght to break in, but still gives black something to think about.
moves.20... c6 21. Ne4: An excellent way to mobilize my knight. I am under 1, here.
moves.21... Qe6: Nc5 seemed ok, but after the queen moves again threatening the knight... I don't see anything really interesting for white's attack.
moves.22. Nf6+ Bxf6 23. gxf6: I keep more chances with the queen on the board. I am threatening Qg7# soon.
moves.23... Ree8 24. Qf4: Simple. Can black stop me? Well, the answer is partly positive.
moves.24... Qd6: e4 comes into consideration, but probably better is h5!. I didn't see this move was intelligent, since prevented my next one...
moves.25. Qh6 Qf8: ...with this. Ok, I don't want to exchange queens. My attack will vanish.
moves.26... h6: Interestingly, black's move has many points. I have no small pieces to sac into the pawns, now (but my knight knows its fate), so they are solid.
moves.27. Qf4 Nc4: Threatening e3. Now, I can defend, but more interesting was...
moves.28. Ng4 h5 29. Nh6+ Kh7 30. Nf5: Opening the king's position should win...
moves.30... gxf5 31. Qxf5+ Kh8: If Kh6, Qg5+, Kh7, Qxh5+, Kg8! (if Qh6, Qxf7... to be considered.)
moves.35. Rdxe4 dxe4 36. Rxe4: but now black has to cover g4 and to defend the knight...
moves.37... Kh8 38. Rxe8: ...this is a more sadistic way to end the game...
